--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:
> Milt,
> Tom is of course right about the motif being a shachihoko.  The 
construction of a copper core sandwiched between thin gold layers and 
finished with a fukurin is not that unusual.  It's seen in Momoyama 
period Ko-Kinko work for example, often with wave and floating mon 
motifs.  Most of these are not as high relief as yours and are 
usually not so crisply carved.  The shape of the hitsu-ana and the 
general workmanship of this one seem more in line with the Edo 
period.  Of course the hitsu-ana could have been enlarged later and 
relined with gold.
> 
> The Genroku period was the next point in time when this kind of 
display was in style.  My guess is that your guard is from that time  
It doesn't look very late to me.  It could possibly be earlier than 
Genroku.  Hard to say more without seeing it.  
> 
> Jim
> 
> 
> 
>   http://tinyurl.com/3cmud
> 

thank you, Jim, -t und Cary  for the insight.
Glad it is not a Yokohama special.......
I will submit this for the NTHK Chicago 04 shinsa.

Milt
